result.markdown:
--- title: "Categorical data" author: Vladimir Buskin format: html: self-contained: true theme: default toc: true number-sections: true slide-number: true incremental: false slide-level: 3 scrollable: true editor: visual bibliography: R.bib --- ## Preparation Please download the file `Paquot_Larsson_2020_data.xlsx` [@paquotDescriptiveStatisticsVisualization2020][^categorical_data-1] and store it in the same folder as your currently active R-script. Then run the code lines below: [^categorical_data-1]: The original supplementary materials can be downloaded from the publisher's [website](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-46216-1_17) \[Last accessed April 28, 2024\]. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Libraries library("readxl") # for loading Excel data library("tidyverse") # data manipulation and visualisation # Load data from working directory cl.order <- read_xlsx("Paquot_Larsson_2020_data.xlsx") ``` ::: ## Frequency tables ### One variable Each categorical variable in the data frame is made up of two or more categories. A simple descriptive measure is the frequency of each category. The table below indicates how often each clause order occurs in the `ORDER` column. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} order_freq1 <- table(cl.order$ORDER) print(order_freq1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` mc-sc sc-mc 275 128 ``` ::: ::: The notation `cl.order$ORDER` subsets the `cl.order` according to the column `ORDER` (see [data frames](Data_frames.qmd)). Alternatively, you could use `xtabs()` to achieve the same result -- perhaps with a slightly more intuitive syntax. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} order_freq2 <- xtabs(~ ORDER, cl.order) print(order_freq2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ORDER mc-sc sc-mc 275 128 ``` ::: ::: ### Two or more variables If we are interested in the relationship between **multiple categorical variables**, we can cross-tabulate the frequencies of their categories. For example, what is the distribution of clause order depending on the type of subordinate clause? The output is also referred to as a **contingency table**. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} order_counts1 <- table(cl.order$ORDER, cl.order$SUBORDTYPE) print(order_counts1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` caus temp mc-sc 184 91 sc-mc 15 113 ``` ::: ::: Here is the `xtabs()` alternative: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} order_counts2 <- xtabs(~ ORDER + SUBORDTYPE, cl.order) print(order_counts2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` SUBORDTYPE ORDER caus temp mc-sc 184 91 sc-mc 15 113 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note collapse="true" title="How do I obtain percentage tables?"} There are two ways to convert the raw frequency counts to percentage tables: 1. Manually divide all cells by the total number of observations (which correspond to the sum of all cells) and multiply the result by 100. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pct1 <- order_counts1/sum(order_counts1) * 100 ``` ::: 2. Use the `prop.table()` function and multiply the result by 100. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pct2 <- prop.table(order_counts1) * 100 ``` ::: ::: ## Plotting categorical data This section demonstrates both the in-built plotting functions of R ('Base R') as well as the more modern versions provided by the `tidyverse` package. ### Moscaiplot A straightforward way to visualise a contingency table is the mosaicplot: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mosaicplot(order_counts2, color = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Barplots The workhorse of categorical data analysis is the barplot. Base R functions usually require a `table` object as input, whereas `ggplot2` can operate on the raw dataset. ### One variable ::: panel-tabset ### Base R - Base R barplot with `barplot()`; requires the counts as computed by `tables()` or `xtabs()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Generate cross-table order_freq1 <- table(cl.order$ORDER) # Create barplot barplot(order_freq1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### ggplot2 - Barplot with `geom_bar()` using the raw input data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load library (if not already loaded) library(tidyverse) # Create barplot ggplot(cl.order, aes(x = ORDER)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ### Two variables Bivariate barplots can be obtained by either supplying a contingency table (Base R) or by mapping the second variable onto the `fill` argument using the raw data. ::: panel-tabset ### Base R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Generate cross-table order_counts2 <- xtabs(~ ORDER + SUBORDTYPE, cl.order) # Create barplot barplot(order_counts2, beside = TRUE, # Make bars side-by-side legend = TRUE) # Add a legend ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Base R (fully customised) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Generate cross-table order_counts2 <- xtabs(~ ORDER + SUBORDTYPE, cl.order) # Create barplot barplot(order_counts2, beside = TRUE, # Make bars dodged (i.e., side by side) main = "Distribution of ORDER by SUBORDTYPE (Base R)", xlab = "ORDER", ylab = "Frequency", col = c("lightblue", "lightgreen"), # Customize colors legend = TRUE, # Add a legend args.legend = list(title = "SUBORDTYPE", x = "topright")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### ggplot2 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load library (if not already loaded) library(tidyverse) # Create barplot ggplot(cl.order, aes(x = ORDER, fill = SUBORDTYPE)) + geom_bar(position = "dodge") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### ggplot2 (fully customised) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load library (if not already loaded) library(tidyverse) ggplot(cl.order, aes(x = ORDER, fill = SUBORDTYPE)) + geom_bar(position = "dodge") + labs( title = "Clause order by subordinate clause type", x = "Clause order", y = "Frequency", fill = "Type of subordinate clause" ) + theme_bw() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ## Plotting percentages ::: {.callout-note collapse="true" title="How do I plot percentages in Base R?"} In very much the same way as with the raw counts: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Create barplot barplot(pct1, beside = TRUE, # Make bars side-by-side legend = TRUE) # Add a legend ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note collapse="true" title="How do I plot percentages with `ggplot2`?"} Here, a few tweaks are necessary. In general, the `ggplot()` function prefers to works with data frames rather than cross-tables, so we'll have to coerce it into one first: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Convert pct1 to a data frame pct1_df <- as.data.frame(pct1) colnames(pct1_df) <- c("ORDER", "SUBORDTYPE", "pct") # Print contents of the new data frame "pct1_df" print(pct1_df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ORDER SUBORDTYPE pct 1 mc-sc caus 45.657568 2 sc-mc caus 3.722084 3 mc-sc temp 22.580645 4 sc-mc temp 28.039702 ``` ::: ::: Now we can plot the percentages with `geom_col()`. This geom (= 'geometric object') allows us to manually specify what should be mapped onto the y-axis: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load library (if not already loaded) library(tidyverse) # Create barplot with user-defined y-axis (requires geom_col()) ggplot(pct1_df, aes(x = ORDER, y = pct, fill = SUBORDTYPE)) + geom_col(position = "dodge") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ## Other plots ### Bubble plot ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the code"} library(tidyverse) # Bubble plot ggplot(pct1_df, aes(x = ORDER, y = SUBORDTYPE, size = pct)) + geom_point(color = "skyblue", alpha = 0.7) + scale_size_continuous(range = c(5, 20)) + # Adjust bubble size range labs(title = "Bubble Plot of ORDER by SUBORDTYPE", x = "ORDER", y = "SUBORDTYPE", size = "Percentage") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Alluvial plot ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the code"} # Make sure to install this library prior to loading library(ggalluvial) ggplot(pct1_df, aes(axis1 = ORDER, axis2 = SUBORDTYPE, y = pct)) + geom_alluvium(aes(fill = ORDER), width = 0.3, alpha = 0.7) + geom_stratum(width = 0.4, fill = "gray", color = "black") + geom_text(stat = "stratum", aes(label = after_stat(stratum))) + labs(title = "Alluvial Plot of ORDER by SUBORDTYPE", x = "Categories", y = "Percentage") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Categorical_data_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Exporting tables to MS Word The `flextable` package greatly facilitates generating publication-ready tables in R. It provides the best output if used on a table created by `xtabs()`. The full guide to this package can be found [here](https://ardata-fr.github.io/flextable-book/crosstabs.html#using-tables). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the code"} # Load library after installation library(flextable) # Create a table tab1 <- xtabs(~ ORDER + SUBORDTYPE, cl.order) # Convert a table to a flextable with as_flextable() output_1 <- as_flextable(tab1) # Print output print(output_1) ``` ::: ![](crosstable_plot1.png) Unfortunately, the output cannot really be customised. However, if you'd like to add some further options, the `crosstable` package provides a remedy. In fact, it is even easier to use as it doesn't require you to compute any tables beforehand. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the code"} # Required libraries library(crosstable) library(flextable) # Create the cross table output2 <- crosstable(cl.order, ORDER, by = SUBORDTYPE, total = "both", percent_digits = 2) as_flextable(output2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

label

variable

SUBORDTYPE

Total

403 (100.00%)

``` ::: :::
